questions.text: A patient was brought into the emergency room by his friend with features of acute intoxication that are attributed to nicotine alkaloids derived from the plant shown below. What category of poisons does this fall under?
questions.solution:
Nicotine is a plant alkaloid derived from the Nicotiana tabacum plant shown in the image above. It is a cardiac poison.

All components of this plant are poisonous except its ripe seeds. Leaves of this plant contain toxic alkaloids, like nicotine, anabasine, nornicotine and lobeline. It is a cardiac poison that initially stimulates autonomic ganglia to produce symptoms of acute intoxication (tachycardia, bradycardia,  hypotension, tachypnea, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and headache). These symptoms later subside to give way to respiratory depression and collapse.

Other cardiac poisons are:

Digoxin is a cardiac poison derived from the roots, leaves, and seeds of the plant Digitalis purpurea (shown below). It acts to prolong the diastolic period of the cardiac muscle. Bradycardia, extrasystoles, ventricular tachycardia, and fibrillation are manifestations of toxicity. Ocular symptoms such as photopsia (colour changes), scotoma, and transient amblyopia can also be seen.

Aconite is a cardiac poison derived mainly from the root and root tubers of the plant Aconite napellus (shown below). Symptoms of intoxication are due to action on the voltage-gated sodium channels on the cell membrane of nerves, and skeletal and smooth muscles. Symptoms consist of intestinal (nausea, vomiting, perioral tingling and numbness, abdominal pain and diarrhoea), cardiovascular (chest pain, palpitations, hypotension, bradycardia), neurological (vertigo and restlessness), ocular (hippus - pupils alternately contract and dilate, diplopia and impaired vision.)

Aconite is an ideal homicidal poison - 

  • Cheap and easily available 
  • Lethal dose is small and short fatal period
  • Taste can be masked by giving it with betel leaves 
  • Cannot be detected by chemical analysis.
  • Also used as an abortifacient, cattle and arrow poison.

Thevetin is a cardiac poison derived from the plant Cerebra Thevetia (yellow oleander). All parts of the plant are poisonous. Symptoms of intoxication are characterized by vomiting, diarrhoea, headache, dizziness, mydriasis, and loss of muscular power. Cardiovascular signs include a weak and irregular pulse rate with hypotension. Possible complications are heart block and cardiorespiratory failure. 

Quinine - Derived from the bark of the Cinchona plant and it causes cinchonism due to repeated therapeutic exposures its symptoms are tinnitus, vertigo, deafness, scotoma, hypoglycemia and arrhythmias. 

Other options:

Option A: Spinal poisons- Strychnine (Strychnus nux vomica), gelsemium. Strychnine acts at the ventral horn by blocking the postganglionic glycine receptor sites in the spinal cord and brainstem. The blockade of these receptors by strychnine results in unopposed muscle contraction, resulting in the classical clinical features such as tonic-clonic seizures, opisthotonus (body arched in hyperextension) and risus sardonicus.

Option B: Deliriants -  Datura, belladonna, hyoscyamus, cannabis, cocaine.

Option C: Asphyxiants -  A toxic or non-toxic gas that causes respiratory embarrassment and leads to unconsciousness or death by asphyxiation. 

Asphyxiants can be classified into:

Simple Asphyxiants Inert gases that displace oxygen
  • Noble gases
  • Carbon dioxide
  • Hydrocarbons
Chemical Asphyxiants Reduce the body's ability to absorb, transport or utilize oxygen
  • Carbon monoxide
  • Cyanide
  • Hydrogen sulphide
Irritant Asphyxiants Damage the respiratory tract
  • Ammonia
  • Formaldehyde
  • Methyl isocyanate
Systemic Asphyxiants Produce significant systemic toxicity by specialized mechanisms
  • Carbon monoxide
  • Cyanide

questions.text: Which of the following IPC sections is not related to grievous injury?
questions.solution:
IPC Section 319 defines hurt (not grievous hurt) that includes bodily pain, infirmity, or disease caused to any individual.

Grievous hurt or injury is defined to include injuries such as emasculation, permanent damage to eyesight (either eye), permanent damage to hearing (either ear), damage to any member or joint, destruction or permanent impairment of the power of any member or joint, permanent disfigurement of the head or face, fracture or dislocation of bone or tooth, and any hurt that endangers the victim's life or causes them severe bodily pain, thereby impairing their ability to follow their daily routine for a period of 20 days. 

Other options:

  • Section 320 - Defines grievous hurt
  • Section 326 - Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt by a dangerous weapon (imprisonment up to 10 years with fine)
  • Section 331: Causing grievous hurt to extort confession (imprisonment up to 10 years with fine) or to compel restoration of property.

Other IPC sections related to grievous hurt:

  • Sec 322: Voluntary causation of grievous hurt.
  • Sec 325: Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt (imprisonment up to 7 years with fine)
  • Sec 329: Causing grievous hurt to extort property (imprisonment up to 10 years with fine)
  • Sec 333: Causing hurt to deter public servant from the duty (imprisonment up to 10 years with fine)
  • Sec 335: Causing grievous hurt on grave or sudden provocations (imprisonment with 4 years + or –fine)
  • Sec 338: Causing grievous hurt by act endangering life/safety of others (imprisonment with 2 years + or –fine)

questions.text: As a part of questioning a criminal, the police beat him on the soles of his feet using a rod. What is this form of torture known as?
questions.solution:
Falanga (also known as Falaka or Bastinado), is a method of torture that involves repeatedly striking the soles of the feet with an object such as a truncheon, iron rod, cable, bamboo cane, wooden pole, or rifle butt.

Other options:

Telefono: This form of torture involves repeated slapping of the sides of the head (over the ears). It may result in rupture of the tympanic membranes or damage to the inner ear.

Chepuwa: This form of torture involves tying the thighs and legs very tightly with bamboo sticks to induce severe pain.

Ghotna: This form of torture involves rolling a wooden log or an iron rod up and down the thigh while the log is being weighted by one or two individuals standing on it.

questions.text: Based on the pattern of postmortem staining shown in the image below, which of the following positions was the body in at the time of death?
questions.solution:
The postmortem staining/lividity in the image provided is characteristic of hanging as it is more marked in the legs, hands, and external genitalia.

Postmortem staining is usually seen in the dependent parts of the body wherein there is gravitational pooling of blood. 

Medicolegal importance - Postmortem staining and its fixation can be helpful to ascertain the time since death. It can also be used to estimate the body's position at the time of death and if the body has been relocated since. 

Other options:

Option A- In supine position (shown below), postmortem staining is limited to the neck and entire back except for the points of contact between the body and the ground (occipital areas, scapulae, buttocks, calves, and heels). The absence of lividity in these areas, due to external compression of blood vessels, is termed contact pallor.

 

Option B- In the prone position, postmortem staining is marked on the anterior surface of the body associated with the presence of Tardieu spots. 

Option C- In a body lying on the side, postmortem staining will is marked on that particular side due to the pooling of blood in the dependent parts.

questions.text: A child presents to the OPD alone, seeking treatment for a minor medical condition. A general physical examination can be performed with just the child’s consent, only if the child is older than ______.
questions.solution:
A general physical examination can be performed, exclusively by the child's consent, if that child is older than 12 years of age.

According to section 89 of the I.P.C, a child under 12 years of age and an insane person cannot give valid consent to suffer any harm which may result from an act done in good faith and for their benefit. In these cases, the consent of the parent or guardian should be taken. If they refuse, the doctor cannot treat the patient even to save the patient's life.

Additionally, a father giving consent for an operative procedure on the child in good faith and for the child's benefit, though the said procedure is risky, cannot be held responsible if the child dies.

questions.text: Given below are substances matched with potential consequences of chronic abuse. Identify the wrong match.
questions.solution:
Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) does not produce physical dependence.

Other substances of abuse that do not produce physical dependence include cocaine, cannabis, and amphetamines. The potential consequences of chronic abuse of LSD are flashbacks or bad trips. 

Physical dependence: Frequent exposure to the drug leads to an altered neurophysiological state. This is characterized by the emergence of tolerance to the drug as well as withdrawal symptoms when the chronically abused drug is discontinued.

Other options:

Option A: Korsakoff syndrome is seen with chronic alcohol abuse. It is characterized by anterograde and retrograde amnesia, disorientation, and confabulation (describing fabricated experiences to fill gaps in memory).

Option B: Amotivational syndrome is seen with chronic cannabis abuse. It is characterized by lethargy and reduced interest in day-to-day activities. 

Option D: Tactile hallucinations seen with cocaine abuse. The affected individual percieves small insects creeping on the skin, giving rise to itching sensations. These hallucinations are termed cocaine bugs or Magnan's symptoms.

questions.text: A police officer has brought the following bullets to you for forensic examination as they were recovered while investigating a crime scene. What is the type of bullet shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The bullet shown in the given image possesses crossed grooves at its tips, which indicates that it is a dum-dum bullet.

Dum-dum bullets are not entirely covered by a jacket; an area near the nose is left uncovered to expose the core. These bullets are designed to expand upon hitting a target. This expansion increases the bullet's diameter, causing a larger wound channel.

Other options:

Option A: A souvenir bullet is one that has been lodged in the body for a long time, with no fresh bleeding around it, and is surrounded by a dense fibrous tissue capsule. 

Option B: Tracer bullets (shown in the image below) leave a visible trace while in flight, which allows the gunner to observe its trajectory. 

Option D: Tandem bullet phenomenon occurs when two bullets are expelled with a single shot; it is seen in the case of firearms that have remained unused or exposed to high temperature and humidity. 

Related Pearl: Types of bullets:

1. Ricochet bullet: Bullet first strikes an intermediate object and then after being reflected strikes the target. It produces a key hole entry wound .

2. Yawning bullet: Travels in an irregular fashion.

3. Tandem (Piggy Back) Bullet Effect: Two bullets are ejected one after the other; first bullet failed to leave the barrel and is ejected by subsequently fired bullet. This occurs due to defect in the weapon or due to faulty ammunition or with loaded firearms unused for several years. Tandem cartridge (also called duplex cartridge) is a single cartridge containing two bullets. 

 

4. Frangible bullet: Fragments on hitting the target.

5. Dum Dum bullet: Tip is chiseled out, fragments extensively on impact.

6. Tumbling bullet:  Rotates end on end during its motion. This produces an atypical entry wound .  

7. Souvenir bullet:  Bullet left in the body for a long time and covered with dense fibrous connective tissue.

8. Tracer bullet: This type of bullet leaves a visible mark or trace while in flight so that the gunner can observe the strike of shot. Rear portion of bullet is filled with mixture of barium nitrate, strontium nitrate and powdered magnesium which is ignited by the burning powder. Mixture burns and sheds red sparks which makes the projectile visible to naked eye which enables shooter to make aiming corrections.

9. Incendiary bullet: It is filled with white phosphorous and ignites the target.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old girl comes to the OPD with her mother. History of penovaginal penetration by the neighbour is reported to the doctor. The girl admits to giving the neighbor the consent for the same and says she does not want to be examined. As a medical officer, which of the following should you do?

1. Document informed refusal
2. Do not inform the police
3. Counsel the mother and daughter
4. Examine with necessary force
5. Inform the police
questions.solution:
In the given scenario 1, 3, 5 are true.

The scenario describes a 14-year-old girl with a history of sexual intercourse with her neighbor albeit with consent. Consent for intercourse is valid only after 18 years in an unmarried girl. As she is less than 18 years, it is presumed to be a medicolegal case of sexual assault.

Examination of a victim of sexual assault should be done after the consent of the victim (if she is less than 12 years of age or unsound mind, consent from the guardian needs to be taken). If she denies examination, counseling has to be done regarding the need for examination and how it could be held up against her in the court of law. If she still refuses for part or whole of examination or sample collection, an informed refusal needs to be documented.

Information to the police is given in all medicolegal cases.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man files a medical negligence case against a surgeon who operated on him for inguinal hernia three and a half years ago. Which of the following defenses against negligence will be applicable in this case?
questions.solution:
Res indicata is the defense against negligence that will be applicable in this case. 

Res indicata specifies that a suit for damages for negligence should be filed against the doctor within two years from the date of alleged negligence. A suit filed after two years will be dismissed as being beyond the period of limitation. Legal action may still be brought up to three years after the alleged negligent act where a patient and doctor have entered into a specific contract that requires the provision of care.

Other defenses against negligence

  • No duty owed to the plaintiff
  • Duty discharged according to prevailing standards
  • Misadventure - This may be therapeutic, diagnostic, and experimental. Therapeutic misadventure is a situation in which a patient has suffered harm or has died as a result of an error made by a doctor or agent of the doctor or the hospital.
  • Error of judgment
  • Contributory negligence - the absence of ordinary care on the part of the patient or his personal attendant
  • Res judicata (S.300, CrPC) -If a question of negligence against a doctor has already been decided by a court in a dispute between the doctor and his patient, the patient will not be allowed to contest the same in another legal proceeding, based on the same set of facts. Multiple appeals cannot be made. 
  • Limitation (Res indicata) - A suit for damages for negligence must be filed within 2 years from the date of alleged negligence against the doctor. A suit filed after two years will be dismissed. But, where a breach of duty to provide care as per a contract between a patient and a doctor is committed, legal action may be undertaken for up to three years from the date of alleged negligence.

Other options:

'Res ipsa loquitur' means 'the thing or fact speaks for itself'. It is obvious evidence of the negligent act committed, such as swabs left in the abdominal cavity post laparotomy.

Related Pearl: Contributory negligence

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

So, contributory negligence occurs when both the doctor and patient are negligent. The direct or proximate cause of the injury should be the patient’s negligence, which means that if the patient was not negligent, the injury could have been prevented.

Contributory negligence usually occurs when the doctor is negligent and the patient:

  • Fails to give an accurate medical history, and as a result, the doctor may misdiagnose or mistreat the patient.
  • Fails to follow the doctor’s instructions
  • Refuses to take the treatment
  • Leaves the hospital against doctor’s advice
  • Does not inform the doctor or seek further medical assistance if the symptoms persist or worsens.

Contributory negligence is a defence for doctor’s negligence in civil cases. However, from case to case, the liability of a doctor may vary from complete non-liability to substantial liability for the damages. Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, the court has the right to hold both parties liable for their negligent actions.

Limitations / Exceptions to contributory negligence:

A. The doctor will be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. The doctor failed to provide proper instructions to the patient

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and did not tell the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (no proper instruction). The patient develops numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

 2. Last clear chance doctrine: It is applicable when the doctor fails to take necessary action to prevent damage due to a negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to take such action.

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and told the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (gave proper instruction). The patient developed numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). Next day patient informed the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said he was busy (There was a clear last chance, but the doctor neglected again). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

B. The doctor/person will not be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. Avoidable consequences rule: It occurs when an injury is caused due to doctor’s negligence, and the patient has done a negligent act, which further aggravated the injury caused by the doctor, and the patient could have avoided the consequence by not doing such act. In such cases, the doctor need not pay anything, and the patient will be held guilty.

  • Ex: A patient had a lacerated wound. The doctor examined the patient and had not done any dressing or provided any antibiotics (the doctor is negligent). However, the doctor instructed the patient to avoid contamination and asked him to visit the clinic next week. When the patient went home, he applied cow dung on his wound every day thinking that the wound would heal faster and didn't visit the doctor after one week. The wound got infected and developed pus and aggravated the injury.
  • Here, despite the doctor being negligent in the first instance, the patient is responsible for his injury as he performed an unnecessary, avoidable act, which aggravated the injury. The doctor need not pay anything.

2. Good Samaritan doctrine: A person who assists another person who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence. unless such assistance is reckless or rash.

  • Ex: A person was travelling on a road and saw a car accident, where the victim was unconscious and was stuck inside the car. He called the ambulance. The paramedical staff instructed him not to mobilize the victim until they arrived. Meanwhile, the car was caught in fire (serious danger), and the person tried to remove the victim carefully out of the car (assisted the victim and was not reckless). However, the victim already had a cervical bone fracture due to the accident, which got mobilized while he was being removed out of the car and as a result, suffered an injury to the spine that led to paralysis (victim’s injury was aggravated). In such a case, the good samaritan doctrine would apply and the person who tried to help, will not be charged under contributory negligence.

questions.text: A young person is brought to the hospital following a snake bite. The attendants have also brought the snake with them for identification. The image of the snake is given below. The poison of the snake is mainly:
questions.solution:
The image shows a banded krait. The poison of this snake is mainly neurotoxic.

The banded krait can be identified by the alternating black and yellow cross-bands along its back and the presence of hexagonal scales. Its tail has a blunt ending with a swelling at the tip. In addition, a black mark can be found on its neck that extends to the eyes.

The initial presentation includes vomiting, hypersalivation, headache, blurred vision, perioral paresthesia, hyperacusis, dizziness, vertigo, and piloerection ('gooseflesh').

Ptosis and external ophthalmoplegia is the first sign of paralysis to set in followed by involvement of the face, tongue, neck muscles, and muscles of deglutition. 

Ultimately, respiratory failure is precipitated either by airway obstruction or paralysis of the diaphragm and intercostal muscles.

The neurotoxic symptoms of the banded krait bite are reversible with the use of antivenoms or anticholinesterase drugs. In some cases the symptoms may even subside spontaneously after a week.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image.
questions.solution:
The image shows postmortem marbling. It is a visible postmortem change that is characterized by linear branching patterns on skin that correspond to the course of superficial veins.

Intestinal bacteria infest the venous system as blood acts as a nutrient medium for their proliferation. There is subsequent hemolysis which stains the vessel walls and the adjacent tissues, giving rise to marbling. This becomes prominent in about 36–48 hours after death in the summer and is distinctly appreciable in the superficial veins of the abdomen, shoulders, chest, and inguinal region.

questions.text: You are examining the injuries in a suspected case of homicide. The shape of the stab wound that you notice is depicted in the image below. What type of weapon might have caused this injury?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a wedge-shaped wound, which is caused by injury with a single-edged knife.

A stab wound occurs when the force is applied into the depths of the body, along the long axis of narrow or pointed weapons like knives, daggers, swords, etc. The depth of the stab wound is more than its length and width.

The size and shape of a stab wound depend on the weapon, the body part that is stabbed, the depth of insertion, angle of withdrawal, the direction of thrust, and the condition of tension or relaxation of the skin. 

The shape of the wound usually corresponds to the weapon used, but the shape of the wounds made by the same weapon may differ on different parts of the body. 

Single-edged weapons cause triangular or wedge-shaped wounds. One angle of the wound will be sharp, while the other will be rounded, blunt, or squared off. If the back edge of the blade is stout, small splits in the skin at the corners of the blunt end of the wound may be seen. These are referred to as fishtailing.

Other options:

Option B - A double-edged knife would produce a slit-like or elliptical wound. Both the edges of the wound are likely to be sharp.

Option C - An ice pick would produce a single small circular wound resembling wounds caused by a small caliber gun.

Option D - A screwdriver would produce a slit-like wound with squared edges.

questions.text: Which of the following features is not seen in mercury poisoning?
questions.solution:
Vineyard sprayer's lung is not a feature of mercury poisoning.

Vineyard sprayer's lung is seen as a result of chronic exposure to copper sulphate spray that is used as an insecticide in vineyards. The pathology consists of histiocytic granulomatous changes in the lung. 

Other options:

Option 1- Danbury tremors are a clinical manifestation seen in chronic exposure to elemental mercury. These tremors initially begin in the hands and then go on to involve the lips, tongue, arms, and legs. They are coarse tremors interrupted by jerky movements. 

Option 2- Erethism is commonly encountered in mirror manufacturing firm employees due to the physiological effects of mercury poisoning. Features include anxiety, depression, irritability, delusions and hallucinations, suicidal melancholia, etc.

Option 3- Pink disease or Acrodynia is the dermatological manifestation of mercury poisoning. Children are usually affected by this hypersensitivity reaction. It is characterized by sweating, skin rash, with hands and feet becoming puffy, pinkish, and painful. Associated paresthesia and skin peeling are also seen.

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of postmortem hanging?
questions.solution:
The absence of a salivary dribble mark is a feature of postmortem hanging. The presence of a salivary dribble is a feature of antemortem hanging.

A salivary dribble mark is the surest sign of an antemortem hanging and is due to the consequence of pressure and friction on the submandibular salivary glands due to the ligature. This results in dribbling of the saliva from the angle of the mouth (angle opposite to the knot). 

The other options are all signs of antemortem hanging.

Option 1 - Oblique ligature mark is seen in antemortem hanging. This is in contrast to the circular ligature mark seen in postmortem hanging. 

Option 3 - Le facie sympathique is the term used to describe the phenomenon when the eye on the same side as the ligature mark remains open with a dilated pupil. This is caused by pressure on the cervical sympathetic chain of that side. It is an indicator of antemortem hanging. 

Option 4 - Tear of carotid artery intima, known as the Amussat's sign, is seen with antemortem hanging. These are transverse tears and are most clearly seen in obese victims and posteriorly placed knots. While the absence of this sign doesn't exclude antemortem hanging, it is never seen in postmortem hanging.

questions.solution:
Desferrioxamine is not an antidote used to treat copper poisoning. It is selectively used as a chelating agent to manage cases of acute iron poisoning, hemochromatosis, and patients with iron overload from repetitive blood transfusions.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a finding seen in the lungs of a stillborn child?

choices.text: Minimal frothless blood on cut section

questions.solution:
The floatation test or the hydrostatic test is negative in a stillborn lung. This test is used to determine the viability of the fetus at birth by immersing the lungs in water. The specific gravity of unrespired lungs (stillborn) ranges from 1.04 to 1.05, while that of respired lungs (live birth) ranges from 0.94 to 0.95 due to an increase in volume from air inhalation. Therefore, a negative floatation test (lungs that sink) is indicative of a stillbirth.  

Other options are signs seen in stillborn children.

Option 1 - Cut section of an unrespired lung in a stillborn child reveals little frothless blood as opposed to the abundant frothy blood seen in the respired lung of a live-born child. 

Option 2 - On gross appearance, the unrespired lung appears uniformly reddish-brown in color. This is in contrast to the mottled pink appearance of the lungs as seen in live-born children, due to the pulmonary vessels being filled with blood. 

Option 4 - The consistency of an unrespired lung is firm, liver-like, and non-crepitant (absent aeration). This is in contrast to the spongy, elastic, and crepitant (evidence of aeration) lungs as seen in live-born children. 

Related Pearl: Hydrostatic Test/Floatation Test/Raygat's Test

It is based on the lung changes in a fetus after respiration.

Principle: Respired air remains in the lungs as residual air which cannot be removed after death. Hence lung floats in water.

False-negative test in:

  • Atelectasis
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Pneumonia
  • Congenital syphilis
  • Air absorbed from air passages if circulation continued for long time after cessation of respiration
  • More air exhaled from the lungs compared to air entering during inspiration
  • Obstruction by alveolar duct membrane

False-positive test in:

  • Putrefied foetus
  • Artificial inflation

Hydrostatic test is not required when:

  • Fetus is monstrous
  • Fetus is macerated or mummified
  • Fetus is born before 180 days of gestation
  • Stomach contains milk
  • Umbilical cord has separated and scar has been formed

questions.text: Which of the following scenarios would impart bright pink-colored postmortem staining?
questions.solution:
Refrigeration imparts a bright pink patchy color to the postmortem staining. This is because of oxyhemoglobin retention within the tissues due to decreased oxygen uptake by tissues. It is also commonly seen in hypothermia and victims of drowning as wet skin is permeable to atmospheric oxygen. Hemoglobin has a greater affinity for oxygen at lower temperatures. 

The normal color of PM staining is reddish-purple. This color varies based on the oxygenation status of the body at the time of death. 

Other options:

Option 1 - Clostridium perfringens septicemia imparts a pale bronze-colored PM staining.

Option 2 - Potassium chlorate poisoning imparts chocolate or coffee-brown colored PM staining. It is similar to that seen in poisoning with nitrobenzene and aniline.

Option 3 - Asphyxial deaths impart a bluish-violet/ purple colored PM staining.

questions.text: Which of the following changes gives an indication of the cause and manner of death?
questions.solution:
Cadaveric spasm is an antemortem change that gives an indication of the cause and manner of death.

The victims do not undergo postmortem flaccidity (unlike rigor mortis), thereby directly entering a state of instantaneous rigor. This results in muscle stiffening which indicates the victim's attitude at the time of death. Cadaveric spasm is limited to select muscles i.e., the muscles that were in a state of contraction at the time of death. The mechanism of cadaveric spasm is thought to be due to neurogenic phenomena. 

Predisposing factors for this postmortem change include excitement, fear, fatigue, electrocution, nervous system injury, and convulsant poisons such as strychnine. 

It persists for a few hours following which, it is replaced by the rigor mortis. 

The image shown above represents a firm hand grip on weeds and mud, found in a victim of drowning. It is indicative of the last action performed by the victim. This is an example of cadaveric spasm.

Other options:

Option 1 - Rigor mortis is a postmortem phenomenon indicative of molecular death. It is useful in estimating the time since death. The mechanism of rigor mortis is due to muscle ATP breakdown below the critical level.  It appears 2-3 hours after death and is usually preceded by postmortem flaccidity. It involves both the voluntary and involuntary muscles of the body and persists for about 12-24 hours. 

Option 2 - Cold stiffening is a postmortem phenomenon that is seen in bodies exposed to temperatures below 3.5 degrees celsius (40 degrees Fahrenheit). The mechanism involves temperature-induced solidification of fat and muscle. Rigor mortis is suspended in these victims and sets in only after thawing. 

Option 3 - Heat stiffening is a postmortem phenomenon that is seen in bodies exposed to temperatures above 65 degrees celsius (149 degrees Fahrenheit). Characteristic rigidity is from heat-induced protein coagulation that causes postural changes due to muscle contraction (pugilistic or boxer's attitude).

The postural changes as seen in cold and heat stiffening occur postmortem in response to the temperature changes to which the body is exposed.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to the emergency room with profound drowsiness. On examination, he is found to have respiratory depression, with a respiratory rate of 5 cycles/minute. His symptoms are traced back to a drug derived from the plant shown below. Which of the following is the antidote to this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The suitable antidote to this patient presenting with features of opiate intoxication is naloxone. The derivative drug, opium is derived from the Papaver somniferum plant as shown in the clinical vignette.

Toxic parts of the plant include the unripe fruit capsule and the latex juice. Active principles of opium are grouped under phenanthrenes (morphine, codeine, heroin) and benzyl-isoquinolones (papaverine, narcotin).

These drugs act on mu, kappa, delta receptors in the CNS and mediate the effects of euphoria, analgesia, respiratory depression, gastrointestinal dysmotility, and miosis. 

The antidote to opiate intoxication is a competitive opiate antagonist named naloxone which competes with opioids at their receptor sites. Dose: 0.4-2 mg IV (It may be repeated every 10-15 minutes up to a maximum dose of 10 mg).

Other options:

Option A - Flumazenil is the antidote to treat benzodiazepine (BZD) intoxication. Benzodiazepines (alprazolam, flunitrazepam) are sedative-hypnotics and symptoms of intoxication include normal vital signs, sedation, diplopia, ataxia, slurred speech, and impaired motor function. Flumazenil acts as a competitive antagonist at the site of BZD action, which is the gamma-aminobutyric acid receptor. 

Option C - Physostigmine is used in the treatment of anticholinergic toxicity due to atropine. Atropine is the anticholinergic active principle derived from tropane alkaloids such as Datura stramonium and Atropa belladonna. Toxidrome consists of features such as tachycardia, hyperthermia, agitation, delirium, mydriasis, dry flushed skin, and urinary retention. Physostigmine is a reversible acetylcholine esterase inhibitor that increases acetylcholine concentrations in the synaptic cleft to mitigate the effects of atropine toxicity. 

Option D - Atropine is used in the treatment of cholinergic toxicity due to organophosphates (DDT, parathion, malathion). Symptoms of cholinergic toxicity include bradycardia, respiratory depression, and autonomic symptoms of salivation, lacrimation, urination, defecation. Atropine used in association with pralidoxime act as competitive inhibitors at the nicotinic and muscarinic acetylcholine receptors to neutralize the toxicity.

questions.text: Which of the following IPC sections deals with causing feticide in a pregnant woman with an intent to prevent a developed child from being born alive?
questions.solution:
BNS Sec 91 (IPC 315) deals with the intent to prevent a child from being born alive or to cause its death after birth. The pre-requisite associated with this IPC is that the fetus must be in an advanced stage of development that would make it sufficiently capable of leading an extra-uterine existence. The offender is liable to imprisonment for up to 10 years, with a fine, or both.

Other options:

Option 1 - BNS Sec 89 (IPC 313) deals with the causation of miscarriage of a woman with child (and/or quick with child) without her consent. Only the person causing the abortion is liable to punishment. 

Option 3 - BNS Sec 88 (IPC 312) deals with the causation of criminal abortion (no therapeutic indication to do so) with the consent of the pregnant woman. Both the pregnant woman and the abortionist are liable to punishment. 

Option 4 - BNS Sec 90 (IPC 314) deals with the death of a pregnant woman from an act intended to cause miscarriage. In such a case, the abortionist/offender is liable to punishment including imprisonment of at least 10 years and a fine. If the act of miscarriage was undertaken after conducting a prenatal sex determination (female fetus confirmation), the offender is liable to life imprisonment and a fine of up to 2 lakh rupees.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the treatment of inorganic acid ingestion is not true?

choices.text: Magnesium hydroxide and bicarbonate is recommended
Gastric lavage and emetics are contraindicated
Administration of milk or egg white is beneficial

questions.solution:
The use of alkaline agents such as magnesium hydroxide or bicarbonate is not recommended for the treatment of inorganic acid (sulphuric acid, nitric acid, hydrochloric acid) ingestion.

The rationale behind the usage of these compounds was that acid can be neutralized by an alkali. However, alkali administration can result in an exothermic neutralization process coupled with gas production in some cases. This could lead to further damage in hollow viscus structures (esophagus, stomach) with a possibility of perforation and further extension of injury. 

Other options:

Option 2 - Gastric lavage and emetics are contraindicated in the treatment of inorganic acid ingestion. This is to avoid further backflow of the acid as well as prevent full-thickness ruptures of the gastric or esophageal structures. Complications may also include peritonitis and mediastinitis due to acid spillage, laryngeal spasm, and respiratory distress. 

Option 3 - Administering prophylactic antibiotics is recommended, especially in cases of suspected or evident perforation. Viscus perforation can lead to gastrointestinal bacterial seeding in the peritoneal or mediastinal spaces with subsequent inflammation (peritonitis, mediastinitis). 

Option 4 - Initial course of action in a case of inorganic acid ingestion includes acid dilution by giving milk, water, or aluminum hydroxide gel. Demulcents such as egg white or starch water may also provide some benefits by forming a protective layer over the damaged mucous membrane.

questions.text: A chronic substance user was brought with complaints of depression, hypersomnia, and craving. History revealed that he had not been consuming the said substance for the past few days. What is the likely substance that was being consumed in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of cocaine withdrawal symptoms.

Cocaine withdrawal is a triphasic syndrome that presents after the sudden stoppage of chronic cocaine use. The phases are as follows - 

  1. Crash phase (9 hours-4 days): Anorexia, depression, excessive craving, hypersomnia, fatigue.
  2. Normal mood, anxiety, and anhedonia (4-7 days)
  3. Extinction phase (7-10 days): Absence of withdrawal symptoms but increased susceptibility to relapse.

Treatment for withdrawal includes bromocriptine and amantadine. They are useful in reducing cocaine cravings.

Other options:

Option A: Shakes, hallucinations, and agitation are symptoms of alcohol withdrawal syndrome. They occur 12-24 hours following alcohol intake. Other features include nausea, vomiting, malaise, anxiety, depression, and headache. 

Delirium tremens begin 72 to 96 hours after the last drink. It is due to the long-continued action of the poison on the brain. It occurs in chronic alcoholics due to temporary excess, sudden withdrawal of alcohol, shock after receiving an injury, such as fracture of a bone, or from acute infection, such as pneumonia, influenza, erysipelas, etc.

Option C: Profuse sweating, diarrhea, and piloerection (gooseflesh) are symptoms of opioid withdrawal. They are associated with nausea, vomiting, lacrimation, rhinorrhea, muscle cramps, and generalized body aches. These symptoms manifest about 12-24 hours after the stoppage and recede within 7-10 days of last use.

Option D: Synesthesia or seeing smells and hearing colors and flashback phenomenon (emotional and psychological experiences of the previous LSD) are features of lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) intoxication. Other features include dry mouth, dilated pupils, tachycardia, hypertension, mood changes, visual hallucinations, alterations in time perceptions, vision, and hearing. Side effects are psychosis, depression, panic attacks, and schizophrenic episodes.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cardinal finding in patients who are declared brain dead according to Harvard criteria for brain death?

choices.text: No pupillary changes in response to light
Absent eye movements in response to caloric testing

questions.solution:
Cough response to bronchial suction is indicative of normal cough reflex and is, therefore not a cardinal finding in brain death. 

The 3 cardinal features of brain death include:

  1. Unresponsiveness or coma- demonstrated by an absent motor response to pain in all extremities.
  2. Apnea- impaired brainstem activity indicates damage to the medullary cardio-respiratory centers. This manifests as a loss of centrally controlled breathing.
  3. Absence of brainstem reflexes -
    • Cranial nerve II, III (optic and oculomotor)- absent direct and consensual light reflex. This is associated with dilated pupils measuring about 9 mm. 
    • Cranial nerve VIII (vestibulocochlear)- absent oculocephalic (Doll's eye phenomenon) and oculovestibular (unresponsive to caloric testing) reflexes.
    • Cranial nerve V, VII (trigeminal and facial)- absent corneal and jaw reflexes.
    • Cranial nerve IX, X (glossopharyngeal and vagus)- absent cough and gag reflexes.

questions.text: Which of the following statements does not apply to cross-examination in a court of law?

choices.text: Witness is examined by the defense lawyer
Objective of cross-examination is to weaken case of opponent
There is no time limit to cross examination

questions.solution:
Leading questions are allowed in a cross-examination according to Sec. 143 IEA. However, they are not allowed during the direct examination conducted by the summoning counsel.

In the event that Judge is satisfied that the witness is hostile, leading questions may be allowed during direct examination. 

Leading questions (Sec. 141 IEA) are defined as questions that suggest an answer that is favorable for the case of the summoning counsel or in alignment with their claim. 

Other options:

Options 1, 3, 4 - In cross-examination, the witness is examined by the defense lawyer or adverse party with an objective to elicit favorable facts to their case, to test the accuracy of the witness statements, to unearth new or old facts, and also, to discredit the witness. 

While leading questions are allowed in cross-examination, the Judge can disallow questions that are indecent (Sec. 151 IEA) or questions asked with an intention to insult or offend the witness in any form (Sec. 152 IEA).

There is no time limit to the duration of cross-examination. 

 

The sequence of examination in the recording of evidence is as follows -

Sequence of Examination Objective
  • Examination-in-Chief/ Direct examination by the party that summoned the witness

To elicit the facts of the case from the witness. Leading questions are not allowed.
  • Cross-examination by the defense lawyer
 To elicit facts favorable to their case and test the reliability of the witness. Leading questions are allowed.
  • Re-examination by the party that summoned the witness
 To resolve doubts that formed during cross-examination and re-emphasize the party's perspective.

5. Witness statements are admissible in court
questions.solution:
The statements true for the magistrate inquest are 1 and 4. 

Sec. 176 CrPC deals with Magistrate inquest or inquiry into the cause of death wherein the circumstances of death are not due to natural causes. Magistrate inquest may be conducted by District Magistrate, Judicial Magistrate, Sub-Divisional Magistrate, or any Executive Magistrate empowered by the State Government (a Sub-Collector or a Tehsildar).

While this type of inquest is practised all over the country, it is not routinely held. 

Indications for a Magistrate inquest include the following

  • Cases of exhumation.
  • Deaths due to dowry (suicide or death of a woman within 7 years of marriage).
  • Deaths due to police firing.
  • Disappearance/death of a person while in police custody or during police interrogation.
  • Death of a convict while in jail.
  • The alleged rape of a woman while in police custody.
  • Admission of a mentally ill person to a psychiatric hospital under certain provisions of the Mental health Act of 1987.

Other statements:

The statements in the question stem compare the salient features of the Magistrate inquest and Police inquest (Sec. 174 CrPC). The latter is conducted by a police officer who is not qualified in law or medicine.

Statement 2- Death while in police custody is a valid reason for a Magistrate inquest.

Statement 3 - An arrest warrant can be issued against the accused in a Magistrate inquest. Although a warrant cannot be issued in a police inquest, the accused may be arrested if there is a cognizable offence. 

Statement 5 - Witness statements made during the course of a Magistrate inquest are not admissible in court. Witness statements made during the course of a Police inquest are valuable and admissible in court.

questions.text:
Match the following types of drowning with their respective mechanisms of death.
Type of drowning Mechanism of death
1. Near drowning A. Laryngeal spasm and airway closure
2. Dry drowning B. Vasovagal inhibition
3. Typical drowning C. Acute respiratory distress syndrome
4. Immersion syndrome D. Pulmonary edema and heart failure
questions.solution:
Correct option 1: 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B

- Near drowning - It is a type of atypical drowning and is also known as post-immersion syndrome or secondary drowning. This type is necessitated by the survival of the drowning victim beyond 24 hours of a submersion episode. Death is due to respiratory decompensation suffered despite responding well to initial resuscitation measures. Mechanisms of death may involve acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), sepsis, hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy, or cerebral edema. 

 

- Dry drowning - It is a type of atypical drowning where the development of laryngeal spasm and subsequent airway closure leads to death. Routine findings of typical drowning are absent during autopsy with dry lung fields as water does not enter the lungs. 

 

- Typical drowning - It is characterized by water inhalation into the lungs, with varying mechanisms for freshwater and saltwater drowning. 

Typical freshwater drowning (hypotonic) is characterized by hemodilution and electrolyte disturbances culminating in ventricular fibrillation.

Typical seawater drowning (hypertonic) is characterized by hemoconcentration and hypovolemia culminating in circulatory shock.

Both types of typical drowning have terminal pulmonary edema and heart failure as mechanisms of death. 

 

- Immersion syndrome - It is also known as hydrocution. It is a type of atypical drowning wherein vasovagal inhibition-induced cardiac arrest is the mechanism of death. Vasovagal inhibition is brought on by cold water stimulation of nerve endings, cold water striking the epigastrium, and entering the external auditory canals, nasal passages, and larynx. 

Another mechanism of death in immersion syndrome is the development of cardiac dysrhythmias that are triggered by sudden contact with water (<5 degrees Celsius lower than normal body temperature). The massive catecholamine surge produced is responsible for the onset of ventricular fibrillation and subsequent cardiac arrest.

Routine findings of typical drowning are absent as aspiration of water into the lungs does not occur.

questions.text: A police sub-inspector brings the accused in a rape case to a doctor and requests a medical examination. He believes that examination findings would yield evidence to prove the offense allegedly committed. However, the accused is not cooperative. What is the next course of action by the doctor?

choices.text: Request police officer for a court order
Refuse to carry out medical examination without consent
Wait until the accused gives consent

questions.solution:
The next course of action by the doctor is to perform the medical examination by force. 

Section 53 CrPC deals with the examination of the accused by a doctor using force, in the event that the examination has been requested by a police officer (designation of Sub-Inspector and above). The intention behind such a request must be to procure evidence regarding the offense allegedly committed by the accused [Sec. 53 (1) CrPC]. If the person is accused of rape, a medical examination may be carried out by force (in the event of non-cooperation) by the provisions made by Sec. 53A CrPC.

Whenever the person of a female is examined, the medical examination must be carried out only by, or under the direct supervision of a female doctor [Sec. 53 (2) CrPC].

Such an examination is applicable to the testing of blood, blood stains, semen, swabs, sputum, hair samples, and fingernail clippings. 

Other options:

Consent is mandatory for the examination of a victim in criminal cases. Performing an examination by force or by availing of a court order is not allowed for the examination of a victim.

questions.text: While carrying out a postmortem analysis of a victim, which of the following features will be consistent with an antemortem burn?

choices.text: Dry, hard and yellow blister base
Absent line of redness around wound

questions.solution:
The presence of carboxyhemoglobin in the blood is highly suggestive of death due to antemortem burns. A blood hemoglobin saturation of >10% with carbon monoxide is indicative of antemortem smoke inhalation.

This is in contrast to postmortem burns, wherein carboxyhemoglobin levels are not elevated as it is not possible for the gas to diffuse through the skin or be otherwise absorbed by a dead body.  

Other options:

Option A: Dry, hard, and yellow blister base is seen in postmortem burns. This is in contrast to the inflamed, red base of blisters seen in antemortem burns.

Option B: Absent line of redness around burn wounds is seen in postmortem burns. This vital reaction, termed red flare, is present in antemortem burns.

Option C: Reduced enzymatic activity around the wound is seen in postmortem burns. This is in contrast to the significant increase in enzyme activity (cathepsin, aminopeptidase, alkaline phosphatase) as seen in an antemortem burn.

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms can cause the skull fracture shown below?

choices.text: Concentrated focal impact on the skull
Forcible contact with a broad resisting surface
Fall from a height onto feet or buttocks

questions.solution:
The image shown is representative of a linear fracture, else known as a fissured fracture, formed on the outer and posterior surface of the skull. They are most commonly caused by forcible contact of the skull with a broad resisting surface like the ground or a wall. 

Linear/ fissured fractures are not associated with displacement of bone fragments and may either involve the complete thickness of bone or either one of the tables. The fracture line follows an irregular course that is parallel to the axis of compression and is almost indiscernible on Xray. 

Diastasis is the term used to describe the weakening of a skull suture when the fracture line passes through it. 

Other options:

Option 1 - Concentrated focal impact on the skull causes a depressed/ signature fracture. Violent blows from blunt objects such as a hammer, damage the bone in the same dimensions as associated with the object thereby producing an impression (signature) of the offending object. 

Option 2 - Oblique bullet wounds cause a furrow due to the removal of a part of the thickness of the skull bone. This gives rise to a gutter fracture. It is frequently associated with a comminuted depressed fracture of the inner table of the skull. 

Option 4 - Fall from a height onto feet or buttocks is the mechanism responsible for a ring fracture. This fracture encircles the foramen magnum and passes through the middle ears and roof of the nose. There is a consequent separation of the skull from the spine. 

Related Pearl: Types of skull vault fracture

Diastatic fracture/ sutural fracture - It involves the separation of sutures due to blow with a blunt weapon or from cerebral edema.

Fissured fracture/ linear fracture:

  • They are breaks in the bone that traverse the full thickness of the skull from the outer to inner table.
  • They are usually fairly straight with no bone displacement.
  • The common cause of injury is blunt force trauma where the impact energy transferred over a wide area of the skull.

Pond fracture/ indented fracture - It occurs in children due to elasticity of bones. 

Depressed fracture/ signature fracture - It is caused by a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. Its shape indicates the type of weapon which is produced (signature fracture).

Comminuted fracture/ spider-web fracture - It has a stellate appearance where there is no displacement of the fracture.

Ring fracture - It is usually caused due to a fall from height landing on feet. These occur in the posterior fossa around the foramen magnum.

questions.text: Which of the following postmortem changes is not a feature of normal decomposition?
questions.solution:
Saponification or adipocere is a postmortem change which is not a feature of normal decomposition.

It is characterized by the formation of a waxy, greasy, and whitish substance with a sweet, rancid odor. it resembles the consistency of soap. The pattern of distribution includes areas of fatty tissues in the dead body. 

Adipocere consists primarily of fatty acids that are produced due to postmortem hydrolysis and the hydrogenation of body fats. It is a water-dependent process that involves the conversion of unsaturated liquid fats to saturated solid fats. 

Medicolegal importance is as follows:

  • It is the surest sign of death
  • It gives a rough estimate of the time since death and
  • The cause of death can be identified. In the face, the features are well preserved and therefore used in identification. 

Other options:

Option A: Right iliac fossa discoloration is the first external sign of decomposition, and is due to the action of C.welchii in the ileocecal portion of the gastrointestinal tract. Bacterially produced hydrogen sulfide combines with hemoglobin to give rise to sulphmethemoglobin which causes discoloration.

Option B: Subsequently, bacterial dissemination takes place through the blood vessels causing similar discoloration of the superficial blood vessels. A linear branching pattern is formed known as marbling.

Option C: The process of decomposition destroys the anatomic integrity of skin which leads to localized peeling known as skin slippage and loosening of skin of hands and feet known as degloving.

questions.text:
A child is brought to the OPD with a history of repeated injuries that seem to be non-accidental. A diagnosis of battered baby syndrome is suspected. Which of the following clinical features are characteristic of the condition?
  1. Subdural hemorrhage
  2. Laceration over forehead
  3. "String of beads" appearance on chest x-ray
  4. Bucket-handle fracture
  5. Bruise over knee
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 3, and 4 are characteristic features of battered baby syndrome.

The battered baby syndrome refers to a constellation of clinical findings suggestive of repetitive physical abuse in a child via non-accidental violence by a parent or a guardian. Additionally, there may be associated deprivation of nutrition, care, and affection. It is usually seen in children less than 3 years of age with a history of emotional or financial problems in the family.

Clinical features:

  • Injuries of different ages and in different stages of healing
  • Bruises may be seen on either side of the chest, behind the axillae, and down the anterior chest wall indicative of the hand impressions of the perpetrator.
  • Violent shaking of a child leads to infantile whiplash syndrome. Repetitive and vigorous shaking of an infant gives rise to a triad of clinical findings—encephalopathy, retinal bleeds, and subdural hemorrhage. 
  • Multiple deformities of the long bones and ribs. Some characteristic fractures include the following:
    • Knob fractures are a result of callus formation in healing ribs that have been damaged due to squeezing. Chest x-ray shows a "string of beads" appearance in the paravertebral gutter.
    • Bucket-handle fractures are typical corner fractures near the metaphyseal regions of the long bones in the arms and legs.

Other statements:

Forehead lacerations, knee bruises, and injuries on bony prominences are non-specific features that may be due to age-appropriate falls. They are usually accidental and not characteristic of the condition.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man is arrested under Sec. 290 IPC for rubbing his genitals against a female passenger in the local bus. Which one of the following terms describes this particular sexual offense?
questions.solution:
Frotteurism is the term used to describe the non-consensual act of rubbing one's genitals against another person for the purpose of sexual arousal and gratification.

Offenders are usually males and these offenses are prone to occur in crowded trains and buses. This sexual offense is liable to punishment under  Section 290 IPC (fine of Rs. 200/-) as well as Sec. 291 IPC (imprisonment for 6 months and/ or fine) for creating a nuisance to the public. 

Other options:

Option A: Voyeurism is a sexual offense wherein the alleged offender observes/ spies on unsuspecting people while they undress, take baths or engage in intercourse with their partners. Their purpose is to obtain sexual gratification. It is a punishable sexual offense under Sec. 354-C IPC by imprisonment (1-3 years) and fine. For the second and subsequent offense, the punishment by imprisonment for 3-7 years.

Option C: Exhibitionism is a sexual offense characterized by intentional genital exposure in public spaces, usually directed towards unsuspecting children and females, to obtain sexual gratification. This offense is liable to punishment under Sec. 294 IPC (imprisonment up to 3 months with/without a fine). 

Option D: Masochism is a type of paraphilia wherein the person achieves sexual gratification when they receive painful stimuli from their sexual partner.

questions.text: Under McNaughten's rule, which of the following criteria is not valid to clear a mentally unsound person of all responsibility?

choices.text: Psychiatric illness while committing the crime
Inability to understand that the act is wrong

questions.solution:
The criterion of the presence of uncontrollable impulse is not included in McNaughten's rule. Therefore, it is not a valid criterion to clear a mentally unsound person of all criminal responsibility.

McNaughten's rule is followed by the British Courts of law to examine the liability of a mentally unsound person who has committed a crime. BNS 22 is the Indian adaptation of this rule. 

McNaughten's rule forms the basis of the legal test of insanity/the 'right or wrong' test. It states that a mentally unsound person is cleared of all criminal responsibility for the crime committed if the following criteria are met:

  • Presence of evidence of psychiatric illness.
  • Existence of psychiatric illness at the time of the commission of the crime.
  • Psychiatric illness is of such a degree that the person does not have the ability to understand the wrongness of the act, i.e., impaired intellectual ability. 

McNaughten's rule decide a person's soundness of mind based on the presence or absence of intellectual ability. However, it fails to consider any impairments in the person's emotional state or the presence of any uncontrollable/ irresistible impulses while committing the act.

questions.text:

  1. Reporting sexual abuse is not mandatory
  2. The act protects individuals <18 years of age
  3. Child pornography is not punishable under this act
  4. The offence is aggravated when committed by police
  5. Sexual harassment is punishable under this act
questions.solution:
The statements applicable to the POCSO Act, 2012 are 2, 4, and 5.

The Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act, 2012 considers all individuals (both male and female) below the age of 18 years as children and protects them from sexual abuse. 

Sexual abuse offenses when committed by a person in a position of authority over the child (police/ member of security forces/ public servant) are deemed to be aggravated.

Offense Punishment If aggravated

questions.text: A forensic expert is assisting the police in investigating the death of a woman. On examination, he notices the Kevorkian sign. What is the estimated time since the death?
questions.solution:
The Kevorkian sign is a postmortem change that occurs in the retinal vessels. It lasts for about 1 hour.

It is characterized by fragmentation of the blood column in the retinal vessels. It appears within minutes after death and lasts for about 1 hour. It can be visualized by using an ophthalmoscope as shown below.

Other postmortem changes occurring in the eye:

  • Cornea - dull, hazy, opaque, wrinkled
  • Flaccidity of eyeballs occurs due to falling in intraocular pressure. IOP reaches zero at the end of 2 hours after death
  • Tache Noir: A film of cell debris and mucus forms two yellow triangles on the sclera on either side of the cornea, with base towards the margin of cornea and apex towards medial or lateral canthus of the eye. It appears within 3-4 hours of death
  • Increase in potassium concentration in vitreous - linear increase up to 100 hours following death. It is helpful in determining the time since death

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with a ​history of perianal pain is brought to the OPD. On subjecting the specimen from the perianal region to a test, it produces yellow rhombic crystals of spermine picrate. What is the test done?
questions.solution:
The test done in the scenario is the Barberio test.

It is used to detect seminal fluid. When saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid is added to the spermatic fluid, yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals of spermine picrate are produced.

  • Stain used: glacial acetic acid and a small crystal of sodium chloride

questions.text: On noticing taurodontism in the postmortem reports of a body, you would suspect that the individual belongs to which of the following races?
questions.solution:
Taurodontism or bull tooth is most commonly associated with Mongoloid race. It is characterized by a wide and deep pulp cavity in molar teeth and fused and bent roots. 

Other common associations in Mongoloid teeth include enamel pearls, which are small nodules appearing on the tooth surface. This race is also frequently associated with shovel-shaped upper central incisors and a congenital absence of the third upper molar. 

Other options:

Negroid races are found to have large teeth, multiple cusps (up to 8) on their molars, and 2 lingual cusps on the mandibular first premolars.

Caucasians have smaller lateral incisors than central incisors (seen especially in females), and long pointed canine roots. They also have small nodules on the lingual surface of their maxillary molars known as 'Carabelli's cusp', which are most commonly associated with Caucasian races.

questions.text: A forensic expert receives the skull of a gunshot victim. What is the sequence of gunshots in this case?
questions.solution:
The sequence of gunshots, in this case, is 1→ 2→ 3 according to Puppe's rule.

Puppe's rule states that the path of a second fracture line does not cross the path of an existing fracture line that appears or was caused before it. This helps the forensic expert determine the chronology (order) in which the bullets were lodged into the skull. 

Puppe's rule is used in forensic examination of skull fractures caused by multiple blunt force vectors as well, as it is not limited to the examination of bullet injuries only.

questions.text: You have been asked to present a case on homicidal deaths by asphyxia, with pictorial representation of the mechanism of attack. You added the following images in your presentation which show death by ________.
questions.solution:
The image shows smothering, which involves the blockage of the external air passages or obstructing the nasal and oral cavities, usually by a hand or soft fabric/ pillow. 

Death occurs due to reflex cardiac arrest rather than due to hypoxia. Examination reveals pallor around the nose and mouth when external pressure is applied using a pillow. Smothering material may yield mucus and respiratory epithelium of the victim. Bruising of the inner surface of the lips and gums may be seen if more force is applied during smothering.

Other options - 

Mugging is a method of strangulation wherein the neck of the victim is caught in the bend of the assailant's elbow. Pressure is usually applied either in front of the larynx or at one or both sides of the neck.

In garroting, the victim is attacked by grasping the throat or by tightening the ligature around the neck from behind.

Throttling is a method of manual compression of the neck by human hands. The cause of death is carotid artery occlusion on both sides.

Road traffic accident - rubbing of epidermis tangential to a rough or hard surface gives rise to graze abrasion also called brush burn. It can occur in a road traffic accident after a pedestrian is being hit by a vehicle and the victim is slid/grazed for some distance before he comes to a halt.

questions.text: A patient firmly believes that his wife has been replaced by a body double with completely identical characteristics. What is the term used to describe this particular delusion?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario the patient firmly believes that his wife has been replaced by a body double with completely identical characteristics. The term used to describe this particular delusion is Capgras syndrome.

Capgras syndrome is a type of delusion of misidentification. In this syndrome, the patients believe that a familiar person or significant other has been replaced by an imposter.

Delusions are firm, false beliefs that persist despite the presence of objective evidence and clear demonstration of their falsity.

Other options:

Option A: Folie a deux is a mental illness where two individuals share a common delusion. They may be a spouse, a child, or any other household member. 

Option C: Persecution is a delusion wherein the patient believes that plans are being made to harm them by close relatives such as a spouse, children, or parents. This delusion may lead the person to harm themselves or the alleged family members.

Option D: Fregoli syndrome is a disorder in which a person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: A man has been arrested and booked under Sec. 80 BNS. Which of the following offences has he been accused of?
questions.solution:
The man has been accused of and arrested for dowry death. Section 80 of the Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS) deals with dowry deaths.

This legal provision comes into effect when the untimely demise of a woman occurs by burns/bodily injury or any other cause apart from normal circumstances within the first 7 years of her marriage. Evidence of cruelty or harassment by her spouse or relatives of her spouse in connection with demands for dowry must be shown. 


Other options:
Option A: Section 105 deals with culpable homicide not amounting to murder. Under this, the convict shall be punished with imprisonment for life, or imprisonment of either description for a term which shall not be less than five years but may extend to ten years, and shall also be liable to a fine if the act by which the death is caused is done with the intention of causing death, or of causing such bodily injury as is likely to cause death. If it is determined that the act is committed with the knowledge that it is likely to cause death, but without any intention to cause death or to cause such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, the punishment is imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to ten years and a fine.


Option C: Culpable homicide is defined under section 100 of the BNS. It states whoever causes death by doing an act to cause death, or intending to cause such bodily injury as is likely to cause death, or with the knowledge that he is likely by such act to cause death, commits the offence of culpable homicide.


Option D: Grievous hurt is defined by Sec.116 BNS. Grievous hurt refers to any hurt that endangers life, or which causes the victim to be in severe bodily pain, or unable to follow his ordinary pursuits for fifteen days. This includes emasculation, permanent privation of the sight of either eye, permanent privation of the hearing of either ear, the privation of any member or joint or the destruction or permanent impairment of the power of any member or joint, permanent disfiguration of the head or face, and fracture or dislocation of a bone or tooth.
